TopicTitle: Kerbal Stuff, an open-source Space Port replacement

Articles.Content:
Kerbal Stuff is a new community-run website for modders to distribute their mods on. It's open source (Python+Flask, with PostgreSQL for persistence) and on GitHub. Pull requests are welcome.

Use this thread for feedback, bug reports, feature requests, or whatever else you want to talk about.

[Mod Edit: Domain now points to something dodgy ]

Edited September 5, 2017 by technicalfool
Removed link.

You might want to enforce strict character limits on the info blurb that goes below the mod's title. It seems fairly easy for these descriptions to be too long to fit in the box, which kind-of defeats the purpose of them.

You rush this thing together in a few hours? Visually ugly and lacking all around.

You rush this thing together in a few hours? Visually ugly and lacking all around.

Wow what an unusually helpful and insightful comment you have. Please show us your open-source space port replacement, so we can comment on it.

First and Foremost, there is no need to insult someone working on something for the community, working for free on their own time. Be respectful, there is no reason to insult others even if you don't like what they've done.

Secondly, if you must be negative, using nonspecific terms to describe your dislikes about any product simply isn't helpful. Stating something is ugly or simply "lacking" doesn't offer much of any usable feedback for its creator. Being specific and saying, "I don't care for how the background looks" or "The buttons color scheme makes them hard to read/use" are helpful. I've admined many forums and designed many clan websites, and I know first hand just how frustrating comments like "I don't like the forum layout" can be.

Thirdly, being constructive is the most helpful. Explaining how you would improve a project is much easier and more helpful for the creator to work off of. By simply offering a suggestion like others have already done in this topic, you give the creator a direction and/or an idea to build off of that they might not have been thinking about before.

At any rate, I for one plan to spend a few hours later today sorting threw the website to see if I see anything that might be helpful for the author, and I hope others will do the same too.

Edited June 26, 2014 by Keldaria

• Users get emailed when mods update

This is my most wanted feature from a mod repository ever (yes, I'm a mod user only).

As for the design, it may not be impressive, but it doesn't need to be. The site primarily needs to be functional, and that seems to be the case. Just one thing: the full-picture background is nice, but it gets annoying when you want to read a mods description. You could maybe put all the text parts in boxes like the mods on the 'browse' page, that helps with reading and still allows a screenshot-based background.

You rush this thing together in a few hours? Visually ugly and lacking all around.

I focused on functionality before aesthetic, which is something I strongly encourage developers to do. I'm very open to hearing suggestions on the style, though, now that most of the functionality is in place.

Edited June 26, 2014 by SirCmpwn
The style is very very nice, I suggest you keep with it
